cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

SATURDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1904.

div.head: THE TENANTS' AGITATION.
div.p: In to-day's issue we publish Mr. Alderson's counterblast to Mr. Chataway's official declaration on the housing question at Alexandria. We need not enter into the merits of this controversy,and we leave it to our readers to decide on the details under discussion. But there is one important argument, brought forward by the opponents of Mr. Alderson's scheme, which is of considerable interest to every European domiciled in Egypt. It has been alleged that Mr. Alderson is fighting on behalf of "aliens," and in to-day's issue we publish a noteworthy contribution on the subject. The writer declares that the whole agitation in favour of decent dwellings for the poorer classes of Egypt's commercial capital is based on a somewhat factitious agitation, "got up" only by the European inhabitants. He points out that there is not a single Moslem on the Tenants Commission, and he asks how it is that such an agitation can be justified if such a large proportion of the population of Alexandria is so loath to sanction any such movement. This argument is plausible, but by no means convincing. Have we not the dictum of the Khedive Ismail Pasha, "Mon pays n'est plus en Afrique, faisons partie de l'Europe," to substantiate the claims of the European proletariat of Egypt to be recognised, not merely legally, as they are by the Capitulations and the Mixed Court, but equit ably in reference to the social conventions habitual in the most civilised cities of Europe. We print an extract to-day from a London contemporary, which is to be laid before the Municipal Commission this evening, descriptive of the efforts made in Berlin to cope with the needs of the poorer classes. Surely Egypt is morally bound to recognise the claims of the Europeans who refuse to live under the same condiions as the native! We do not for one moment wish to depreciate. the social conventions of our Moslem friends, but it is obvious that they can carry on the business of existence at a far lower cost than even the poorest class of Europeans. Have not he Europeans, therefore, any claim to onsidération on these grounds. We think they have, for Egypt is virtually no longer an African but a European country. If e do not grapple with the problem before it gets too great, we shall find ourselves face to ace with a most serious difficulty
TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR.
div.p: 203 METRE HILL.
ATTEMPTED RECAPTURE.
RUSSIANS REPUISED.
TOKIO, December 2.
The capture of the 203 metre hill opens the way to the town and harbour of Port Arthur from Pigeon Bay, and will probably prevent the retreat of the garrison from Liao- Ti-Shan. (Reuter.)
TOKIO, December 2.
It is reported that a strong force of Russians attempted to recapture the 203 metre hill, but were repulsed with heavy loss.
It is announced here that 17 officers were killed and 64 wounded during the recent fighting at Port Arthur.
(Reuter.)
TOKIO, December 2.
Seventeen officers were killed and 64 wounded in the last battle at Port Arthur. (Havas.)

div.head: GENERAL NEWS.
div.p: HAGUE CONFERENCE POSTPONED.
WASHINGTON, December 2.

Russia's suggestion to postpone the Hague Conference necessarily prevents the United States from taking any further steps in the matter at present, as it is desirable that Russia should participate. (Reuter.)
NAVY REFORM.

LONDON, December 2.. The Standard learns that the chief reform in the Navy will be the strengthening of the Home Fleet so as to secure a preponderance from Portland as far as the Firth of Forth. The Admiral in command will eventually be the senior officer afloat. Gibraltar and Hong- Kong are to be improved as bases. (Reuter.)
PORTUGUESE TRANSPORT WRECKED.

ADEN, December 2. The Portuguese transport Sao Thome, which left Lisbon on the 10th inst. bound for Macao, has been wrecked in the Red Sea. 344 troops were landed here. They will proceed by a British steamer. (Reuter.)

div.head: TANGIER
div.p: ATTEMPTED CAPTURE OF CORRESPONDENT.
TANGIER, December 2..
The mountaineers determined to capture Mr. Harris, the Times correspondent, by rushing his house, which, however, was guarded. The attempt failed. The British Minister has lodged a protest. (Reuter.)

div.head: MARSEILLES STR K.
div.p: DEBATE IN FRENCH CHAMBER.
PARIS, December 2.
The Chamber of Deputies is debating on the Marseilles strike. M. Pelletan, Minister of Marine, justified the action of the Government.

div.head: DEATH OF MO KPNIZ
div.p: (Havas.)
VIENNA, December 2. (Havas.)
M. de Kapnitz is dead.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: H.H. the Khedive arrived at Abdeen Palace yesterday morning and visited the Mosque of Amr for prayers at 11 a.m. The old mosque had been brilliantly, perhaps a little garishly, decorated and great crowds, rather hard to keep within bounds. had gathered to see his Highness pass, followed by the Ministers, Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha, Adly Pasha Yeghen, the Ulema, and many high functionaries. The guard of honour was composed of the 16th Battalion, with the cavalry band, and the usual salutes were fired as the Khedive entered and
left the mosque.

div.p: The P. & O. 8. N. Company's Steam Yacht "VECTIS," 6,000 tons, will leave Alexar dria on Friday, the 9th and 30th of D cember for MARSEILLES, taking Fir t Saloon Passengers only, at the usul mi

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea Central position. Under English management 81-11-904

div.head: MANCHURIA.
div.p: PURSUING THE JAPS.
POSITION RUSHED.

ST. PETERSBURG, December 2. General Kuropatkin reports that a scouting party rushed a Japanese position west of the Sha-Ho during the night of the 30th November and bayoneted 25 men after a stubborn resistance. The Japanese fled and were pur- sued to the Sha-Ho. A number of rifles, equipment, and blankets were captured. An exactly similar affair took place during the same night on the Russian left. A second force was sent to assist in the pursuit of the Japanese, south of Tsin-khe-chou, which is still proceeding. Unofficial telegrams state that General Rennenkampf is directing the pursuit personally. (Reuter.)
MUKDEN, December 2.
Colonel Water, Military Attaché, has left for England. He has permission to return in the spring. (Reuter.)

div.head: PARIAH DOGS.-
div.p: Stray and ownerless dogs found in the Moharrem Bey and Ramleh districts to-night will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: A MAIL FOR EUROPE,
div.p: viâ Port Said and Brindisi, will be made up at the General Post I Office, Alexandria, and dispatched at 8.30 a.m. on Monday.

div.head: INSPECTION.
div.p: Major General Slade and staff i proceeded to Helouan very early on Friday, and after breakfast at the Tewfik Palace Hotel, F inspected the camp of the Royal Engineers I which is pitched on the ground adjoining the m hotel.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.-
div.p: On the 30th ult. 16 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 9 were British, 2 German, 1 Egyptian, 1 French, 2 Dutch, and 1 Italian. The transit and passen- ger dues for the day amounted to 368,837.14 frs. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the 1st, to that date on 398 vessels amounted to 10,337,254.05 frs.

div.head: A GENERAL NEED.-
div.p: One proof of the necessity of a knowledge of languages to all classes of men may be found in looking over the list of pupils in the Berlitz Schools. One finds there the names of modest employees along with those of high functionaries, both at the school in Alexandria (26, Rue de l'Eglise Copte), and in Cairo (1, Sharia Kamel). The satisfaction of all is great and perfectly unanimous. [Advt.]

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Marquis Salvago-Raggi will arrive at Alexandria to-day to meet Marchesa Salvago- Raggi, who is expected from Europe to-morrow.

Among the passengers who are arriving at Port Said on Monday by the Bibby liner Warwickshire are Lord and Lady Rathdonnell, Sir Augustus and Lady Hemming, Mr. Arthur Chamberlain and Miss Chamberlain, General
Lance, and Colonel Fitzroy.
M. and Mme Pierre Girard arrived in Cairo yesterday for a fortnight's stay.

A marriage has been arranged, and will take place at All Saints' Church, Bulkeley, on the 18th Jannary, 1905, between Mary Evelyn, daughter of Mr. John T. Burton, Alexandria, and Mr. Arthur H. Payton, of Solihull, War- wickshire.

Mr. Keith Lang, the manager of the Na- tional Bank of Egypt at Alexandria for the last three years, left Egypt with his wife yesterday for good by the French packet. Mr. Lang intends settling in Inverness-shire for a year at least, as he has been ordered to rest by his medical advisers in consequence of the effects of the accident he had last year on the Khedivial Sporting Club's grounds.

THE BALTIC FLEET.
IN THE RED SEA.
MAKING FOR DJIBOUTI
TANGIER, December 2.
The supplementary Baltic Fleet has arrived here.
(Reuter.)
PERIM, December 2.
Two large and two small Russian men-of-war have passed southwards.

(Later). The whole of Admiral Foelkersham's squadron has passed. A small French steamer. from Djibouti met the squadron north of p Perim. It is probable that she supplied pilots E for Djibouti, whither the Russian squadron is making its way.
(Reuter.)

div.head: NAVAL NOTES.
div.p: Suez Friday. The Dutch cruiser Hertog Hendrick came out of the Canal yesterday s morning, and sailed shortly after bound to t Batavia. T
H. M.'s first-class cruiser Hogue came out of th the Canal yesterday afternoon, and is now th coaling in the bay.
H. M.'s second-class cruiser Hermione enter th ed the Canal at 6 o'clock this morning bound w to Malta. The Hermione was stationed at L Suez for some time, pending the arrival of the R Baltic Fleet.

Port Said, Friday.-H.M.S. Furious, second-ha class cruiser (Capt. H. Loftus Tottenham), st lately guardship at Port Said, left this morn-m ing for Portsmouth, calling at Malta en route. W H.M.S. Hermione, second-class cruiser (Capt. so Frederick S. Pelham), with the crew of H.M.S. th Fox, is due at Port Said early to-morrow no morning from Suez. She is also bound for in Portsmouth-via Malta.
YACHTING.

The turbine yacht Emerald, chartered by French tourists, after being in the Red Sea for a couple of days, apparently to have a good view of the Russian. Fleet, returned to Suez, and is now moored near the French yacht Fiorentina.

The P. and O. Company's S. Y. Vectis, which is having a successful cruise in the Mediter-ranean, is due at Alexandria from Malta on Monday morning next at 10 o'clock. She has a number of distinguished tourists on board.

ALHAMBRA THEATRE.

Last night, M. and Mme Fedik gave their first entertainment at the above theatre. The -programme was an excellent one and of the character which in London we associate with the Egyptian Hall and the names of Maskelyne and Cook. While, however, the latter claim to produce their effects entirely by sleight-of-hand

and mechanical means, M. Fedik claims to bring to his aid occult powers and what the French term "spiritisme." The entertainment was divided into four parts the first a con- juring one, the various tricks being very clever- ly performed. This was followed by experi ments on Mme Fedik while in a state of cata dlepsy, two or three of which, obviously painful to the feelings of the audience, might with advantage have been omitted. The third part was the most wonderful, and consisted of the escape of Mme Fedik from a sack tied at the mouth and sealed, and placed in a box 1 which was securely locked and well corded. This was put under a light draped framework, and in less time than it takes to write this, the t lady appeared dressed as when she was tied up v in the sack. The box was then unlocked and fi M. Fedik was found to have taken her place, the seals on the mouth of the sack being intact.c The concluding part was the least satisfactory, fl but if the claim to produce apparitions on a transparent glass screen by occult means is a a well-founded one, we can quite understand that "conditions'' last night were as unfavour-la able to success as can well be imagined. The night was stormy and cold, the wind whistled through. the building, the male portion of the audience mostly wore overcoats and turned fr their collars up, and were obviously tired-out, cold, and uncomfortable. We should like to see the "Magic Mirror" under more favourable con- ditions. The waits between the parts were tedious and tended to spoil the effect of what otherwise would have been a bright and interesting entertainment, in spite of the unfavourable weather.
THE CATTLE PLAGUE.
ANOTHER OUTBREAK.
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).

Medinet el-Fayoum, Dec. 1. Cattle plague has reappeared in the Fayoum, and a district, fifteen kilometres in diameter, is considered infected. The plague first re- appeared at Keboushah village and esbets. The Sanitary Administration has dispatched an English inspector and a supply of serum. I understand that this unfortunate recru- descence has arrived in the Fayoum on this occasion through animals sent here from Cairo.
BUBONIC PLAGUE.
According to the weekly note on the bubonic
of plague, 2 cases have occurred in the whole of
s Egypt during the last week. Both cases were
s pneumonic in character and terminated fatally. They occurred, as in the previous week, at El Amar, Toukh Markaz.
MARCO FOSCOLO.

A large and representative gathering as- sembled last night at the New Khedivial Hotel to hear the young violinist Marco Foscolo. The programme was a varied one and gave f the audience ample opportunities of gauging the capabilities of the young performer. It will be impossible to do more than touch upon the performance generally, but the two items which call for especial notice were the exquisite Légende of Wieniawski and Beethoven's Romance in F major. Both these pieces were well interpreted and the violinist seemed to have a due appreciation of the pathetic and stirring harmonies which make the first- mentioned such a favourite. In the Mazurka of Wieniawski's it must be confessed he was not so successful: he hardly seemed to have caught the spirit of the music, and there was a noticeable lack of rhythmic appreciation, while in one or two places the bowing was harsh. On the other hand the performer seemed a little too much at home in the beautiful Madrigale of Simonetti which concluded the programme, and as a result his interpretation was some- what slovenly but with these few exceptions, 1 the performance must be reckoned as a distinctly good one, and as it is but just to view a maiden effort more by the light t of future development and potential power. than by the actual rendering presented, it a may be confidently asserted that with careful 8 study and the maturing of the mind which the years will bring Marco Foscolo has a successful 7 if not a great career before him. His executive power is certainly exceptional for a violinist of W his limited experience, and his rendering of t Schubert's L'Abeille was practically faultless.a He has a pleasant manner, and a reserve as t becoming as it is rare, and we can only hope t these two indubitable hall-marks of artistic d genius will stand him in good stead in an age when so much art is merely meretricious.

Mlle Hoesli contributed one or two very pleasing items to the programme, the most ti noticeable of which was a charming little lullaby by L. Ketten, very prettily sung and quite free from that affectation which so often characterises the rendering of that class of music. Massenet's Air de Salomé rather lacked dramatic precision, and a song by Hofmann for entitled Sehnsucht, though well rendered, th suffered somewhat from the vocalist's evident want of acquaintance with both words and music. Mlle. Hoesli has a distinctly fine organ and it must be confessed she was a valuable asset in an altogether very enjoyable performance.

"AIDA" AT THE VERDI,

The new Cairo theatre opened on Thursday night as a Cairo theatre should-with Aida; and we must pronounce the début a complete success. The theatre itself, the staging, scenery, orchestra, and singing were all highly commendable, and the house was well filled. Aida is an opera which must always com- mend itself to Cairenes, and last Thursday night's presentation of it augured well for all concerned in the new venture. In the first place the orchestra was distinctly successful. The 2nd act was certainly loud, but after all, the trumpets are a part of the ensemble, and necessary to the effect. Let us at once con- gratulate the company on possessing so able a member-a star indeed-as Signa. Popovici. Throughout, her voice and acting were alike unexpectedly admirable, so much so as to dwarf in a measure, her colleagues, good as these were. Her rendering of the duet in Act III. was beyond praise. We hope to see her fill many more parts, and are confident that she will again deserve the full meed of applause so rightly accorded to her on this her first appearance. Sig. Baldelli, as Ramphis, deserves high praise for his quiet and dignified acting, appropriate in every way to the part. Signa. Fabbri showed to great advantage, in the last act especially; indeed all were at their best in the finale. Sig. Venerandi gave his ex- cellent voice its full scope and delicacy. Perhaps Sig. Queirolo, as the King, was too conventional, but the part militates against any real display 1 of power or emotion; it is essentially one of the lesser parts. We must admit that the act-1 ing was rather "operatic," and too much underlined in parts. Where the performers 1 showed to the best advantage was therefore in 1 the crucial moments of emotion. But after all
ad this seems to be the fault, almost the tradition, e
it-

I

We would recommend those to whom they befall fto direct their attention to these. Though they are productive only of small (and, we hope, only temporary) inconvenience, such details are apt to annoy the public needlessly and to preju- dice their appreciation. On the whole, we sincerely congratulate theatre and company alike, and hope for many more such performances which may serve to prove what a real acquisition the Verdi Theatre is to Cairo.
THE TENANTS' COMMISSION.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Sir, The only proof that need be brought forward to show the want of any firm basis for the present agitation in Alexandria on the question of rents is that not a single Moslem or Copt is on the Committee of the Tenants Commission, so about five-sixths of the population of Alexandria are not interested in the matter, which is evidently an agitation "got up" by a few discontented Europeans. I am, etc.,

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: MAIDEN HOCKEY MATCH AT SUEZ.

A further development of Suez's sporting aly activity took place yesterday, when the Exiles ed. played a maiden hockey match versus H.M.S. m-Hogue. The honours fell to the visitors, who scored seven to nil.

MENA HOUSE GYMKHANA.

nd Rain, dust, wind, and yet more wind, was n- the order. of the day at the Mena House le Gymkhana yesterday afternoon, and it followed ci. that the Gymkhana suffered. A good few ke visitors got as far as the hotel, lunched, and to went no further, feeling no doubt that to as watch races on a bleak afternoon would be an anticlimax. Those who reached the course filled ee the grand-stand, and watched for a longer or nt shorter time, but there were not many spectators on the ground during the last two races, er which was a pity, for the wind charitably is dropped and these events gave much amuse- ed ment. Capt. McMurdo judged the racing, t. helped by Capt. Beales, and the prizes, which in deserved to be competed for by larger fields,

By kind permission of the officer command- ing, the Band of the 2nd Royal Inniskilling 11 Fusiliers played a series of selections during y the afternoon. Mr. Weckel's arrangements y were worthy of a finer day. By the way, we ot noticed some improvements at Mena House, 1- of which we shall have more to say anon. We may, however, mention the enlargement of the hall, the additions that have been made s to the garden, and the new reading-room.
t
B
t
UPPER NILE AUTOMOBILE ROAD.

The Congo authorities are about to lay down a high road for automobile traffic be- tween the Congo River and the Nile. The projected road will facilitate and expedite trading intercourse between the Uelle district in the north-east and the Nile and the districts traversed by the navigable reaches of the Congo; while at the same time it will bring about quicker communication between Antwerp and the Upper Nile. The new road will start from the native village of Buta, which lies on the river Itimbiri, which is a tributary of the Congo, and is navigable to Buta, and its end, will be at Redyaf, on the Nile. The length of the road will be 800 miles, although the actual distance is about 530 miles; but the mountain chains and swamps will be avoided. Workmen are now at work at both ends, under Belgian engineers and foremen, each of the latter being in charge of a gang of 200 negroes. Three motorwaggons are already running from Redyaf for a distance of 20 miles. As the soil proved to be so soft, the first waggons, weighing five tons each, have had to be replaced by others weighing only three tons each. Six ox waggons are journeying between Redyaf and Faradyi so successfully that 12 other light ox- waggons, each to carry one ton of goods, have been ordered for use at Redyaf.

div.head: THE HOUSING QUESTION
div.p: AT ALEXANDRIA
AN INTERESTING EXAMPLE.

The following extract from the Daily Mail of the 18th ulto., is to be laid on the Muni- cipal Council's table by Mr. Alderson tonight, as an example for Alexandria:- Nothing in Berlin so much impresses me as Rixdorf, the Whitechapel of the German capital. You know the East End of London the stifling courts, the grimy alleys; the roaring taverns, the tattered children, the suffocating reek of frying fish, and the groups of gossipin slatterns at every gloomy doorstep. You know all this, and everybody is sick to death of the subject, sick to death of it in spite of the virtue and endurance which flourish there like flowers on a muck-heap. Everybody feels that Whitechapel is there for ever, as inevitable and persistent as the fogs, the rains, and the smuts of London. The thing cannot be altered; there- fore let it be.
INSIDE A GERMAN HOME

was a police-office. "Yes!" he said, bitterly "they live with us; even in our houses! The Control; always the Control!" I asked to be allowed to enter, and, having a magic name or my lips as an introduction, I was permitted to inspect the place. The police greeted me in a pleasant fashion, taking their cigars from their me information. As we passed out and stood mouths, and pausing, in their games, to give for a moment looking at the photographs and descriptions of missing citizens on the wall, agreeable enough. told my guide that the police seemed to be

Here, for instance, is the home of a man who keeps a little green grocer's shop in his front room. On the walls A stove filled with hot bricks diffuses a pleas are shelves bright with polished china and tin. ant warmth, and shines in all its tiles with the labours of the housewife. A table spread with and is set out with, the frugal tea of the little a neat cloth occupies the centre of the room. family. The grandmother with a warm shawl over her shoulders sits in a high-backed chair only the strings. The people who pull the "They are all right," he said: "but they are beaming at her visitors; the good housewife-strings--ah, those are the devils. You should radiantly clean-hangs over the back of the see them! O, my Heavens, you should !”-- chair nodding a sympathetic head at every twist of the conversation. Big and burly, leaning against the wall, with his cap in his hand, THE CHIEF ASSET OF EMPIRE. his arms folded across his deep chest, is the But I saw no brutalising evidence of the master of the household-an ex-seaman with Control in my wanderings. I entered little beer-houses, comfortable places, with tables and shining dark black hair, and a red face. The big boar-hound, which pulls the vegetable-chairs, and music going cheerfully through the Now let me show how another European city against the legs of the English visitor and cart through the streets, presses his full weight of the people. They have their beer-gardens evening, and saw no check upon the enjoyment houses its working-classes. Come with me into drives him slowly and resolutely to the wall, in Rixdorf, their music-halls, and their places the "slums" of Berlin. where he holds him prisoner till the master, for lectures and Socialist meetings. They walk laughing, and the housewife, apologising, call through the broad streets and pay calls at each him off. We learn from these good people that other's houses, and crowd to the Templehofer they have their hard times, and that it is often Feld to see the great military reviews. It seem difficult to dress the children as they could ed to me that they are in happy circumstances. wish; but, nevertheless, they never go short of food; no, no; that does not happen in Berlin. As for work, why, life would be a poor thing without it, and there is usually an hour or two in the evening when they can go and hear music at the café. Oh, yes; they are comfort able enough, and Berlin is pretty good, as cities go. But the country-ah, that's fine, that is.
RIXDORF.

From the centre of the city, with its splendi1 houses and its ceaseless shops, an electric tram carries one swiftly to Rixdorf-a district con- nected by every possible means with every quarter of the city, however fashionable or magnificent. And when you reach it you scarcely know that you have left the fashion able quarters at all. For on every side of you are spacious streets, with trees planted at the kerb, and on either hand tall white palaces rising up with solid dignity towards a clear sky,
eyes,
THE CONTROL.

Huge houses, bright and speckless, with wide doorways, many shining windows, and iron-" It was the same in every house I visited., railed balconies, where creepers twine and Extraordinary cleanliness, a quiet cheerfulness, children play. Splendid and noble houses, and a devotion to the work of the home. The such as you would look for with difficulty in almost any quarter of London. It is here that the working-classes of Berlin live out their careful, thrifty, and laborious lives."

babies lie in snowy linen, with smothering quilts over their feet; the kitchens shine and gleam with eternal polishing; and the sitting- rooms are cheerful and neat, with a solidity about the furniture and a simplicity about the hangings which reflect the character of this stubborn and ambitious people.
But everywhere, even in this orderly quarter of the city, there is evidence of what the Berlin-

The jerry-builder does not exist in Berlin. As soon as land falls vacant it is purchased by companies of recognised repute, often by bank ing houses, and only such streets are planned which meet all the requirements of sanitation and art. The houses are built, and the working ers hate and resent more than anything else classes enter thein, the well-off renting the ground and first floors, the poorer folk mount. "Look!" said my guide, a working man, as ing to the floors above. From the doorstep to the fanlight in the roof everything is clean and orderly.

we mounted the stairs of one of these Rixdorf palaces. His hand pointed to a door on the first floor, and I saw to my amazement that it
Now, I saw during all my wanderings through Rixdorf one half-drunken man, but never did I see a drunken woman. I am told that drunken- ness among the women is unknown..?

If drunkenness broke out among the women, be sure that Berlin would legislate against it with a swift hand. For in Germany (where, as an athlete trains for a race, a whole nation is training for the great struggle for commercial supremacy) the absolute health and vigour of prosperity is regarded as the first charge of municipal government. The health of the work- German Empire by German statesmen. man is reckoned as the chief asset of the. How odd that sounds in England!

div.head: MR. ALDERSON REPLIES.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir, I noticed in our esteemed Administrator of Municipality's letter, re the housing problem, that he does not appear to be completely in agreement with me, so I will try to answer his remarks. No doubt, the problem is difficult and delicate, and it being my first attempt, I am perfectly willing to accept his statement that I have not treated it rightly and that the matter requires more careful study. During the last few months this question was brought to my notice and, on my return from Europe, I immediately took it up and visited personally many quarters of the city with the workmen themselves, and found that the discontent did not arise from want of work or wages or high rents, but from want of accommodation which does not exist. Therefore, I arrived very easily to the conclusion that some plan must be evolved by some one to supply this want. Therefore I have presented the following plans and a project for the consideration of my fellow Councillors.
Now, I will reply categorically to Mr. Cha- taway's criticism on my project:
1. Re building accommodation for a favourite few:

If you read my project and examine the plans, you will see that the whole scheme, for which I ask 30,000 m, of land, is for 7 such blocks, which would accommodate probably say 1,000 families, or more.
2. Distress.
As regards distress existing, I have not brought forward this plea, but for want of other accommodation the people are obliged to live in unhealthy houses, which is a danger to the
town.
3. Mr. Chataway asks what is the cause: -Is it that trade is bad?
-No.
Is it that they are unable to earn their living?
-No.
-Is it that the supply of labour is more than the demand?
-No.
4. As Mr. Chataway remarks: "Alexandria was never more prosperous."
-But it is the want of decent and healthy 5 apartments, where the workers can go home to c after their day's work, that is the trouble.

5. As to the further question: Is it that the artisan has aquired expensive habits and lives at a rate their income does not justify? -No one, who has visited them in their "rat-holes," as I have stigmatised them, could have the heart to make such a remark, nor imagine that they had any luxuries. The only luxury they are demanding is, as I have remarked above, a decent and healthy place with light and air.

6. As to Mr. Chataway's statement that: "It is an unnatural condition of affairs, caused by either the fault of the artizans or by the fault of the capitaliste." I reply that "It is neither, but the eternal law of supply and demand." The Remedy is to build accommodation for artisans.
7. With regard to Mr. Chataway's remark as to the wage offered not being at a proper market rate, I declare that this I have never stated.
8. Mr. Chataway says: "Proprietors are raising the rents constantly." I answer, "Certainly, as I have explained to the artisans, and so should I, as long as the demand lasted.

9. With regard to the notice of the error 1 have fallen into as to working out a scheme for the relief of the poor, and indeed only a very small portion of them. I beg to state that my scheme is not for the relief of the poor but it is to provide accommodation for good, industrious, healthy, hard-working artisans, on the theory given in an extract taken from the Daily Mail, and which is published in to-day's Gazette, that "The health of the workman is reckoned as the chief asset of the statesmen of the German Empire."
As I have before stated, the whole scheme, which I hope to live to see carried out, is very comprehensive and would accommodate very the large numbers. by
10. Re my demand for the Municipality to administrate, I think we shall be less liable to get in the same state again as regards article sans' tenements, if they did so.

11. Re 3% guarantee: The object of this is that, inasmuch as I want the shares to be kept pre till they are disposed of to the artisans them £9 selves it would facilitate obtaining the loan, ove without falling into the hands of capitalists,
12. Re remitting 2% tenants' tax, of tene ment only paying. £l a month's rent, the cost of collecting would swallow up the receipts.

13. Re the 6 per cent, interest, being exorbitant for the capitalists to obtain, I answer that I do not want the capitalists to obtain it, but I do want the artisan to have a safe profitable investment for his small savings and to know where he can get this as he saves a Sovereign.

14. In regard to the cost of the building, I declare that I hope, if my project is, passed, with the help of the artisans themselves, to reduce this to say, perhaps LE, 15,000, and as many of these houses will be subdivided, and if some pay more than £1 a month, we shall arrive to the 10% on actual cost.
I base the 10% on the following scale: 6% dividend, 1 for repairs, 2 for amortissement, i.e., 2 say on £20,000 equals £500, £500 invested at 3% will bring in 25 years say £20,000,

As regards, my demand for water: This, I consider a necessity for the health of the town and should be paid for by the Municipality. As to light: Well, I only meant light to be paid for by the Municipality in the corridors. Of course all schemes must have a beginning, and I begin by proposing one block, for which m these conditions I have, in my circular, offered to find the capital at my expense, till built, and handed over to Municipality and take charge of building this block myself.
Signed:

At the last annual general meeting a special resolution was passed, and duly con- firmed at a subsequent meeting, amending the Memorandum of Association of this company, in order that capital might be invested in companies formed for the purpose of land purchases.

In April, 1904, a company entitled The Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Ltd., was formed with a Capital of £100,000 in shares of £1 each, of which this company subscribed for 10,000 shares, the remainder being offered to the proprietors of this company in the ratio of one share for each share held by them.

One of the conditions in the formation of this company was that a majority at least of the Directors of the Land Company should be selected from the Directors of this company. The Metropolitan & Cairo Helouan Railway Company.

In July, 1904, special resolutions were passed at an extraordinary general meeting of the proprietors and duly confirmed at a subsequent confirmatory meeting authorising the purchase of the railway between Cairo and Helouan, and other properties, by an issue" of 11,103 further. 5 per cent. Cumulative Preference Shares of £10 each.

All the necessary legalities for this purchase have been completed for some considerable time, and the Directors only now await the formal sanction of the Egyptian Government which must be obtained before taking it over. Extensions.

New Capital.
For the construction of new lines and for the purchase of additional rolling stock, necessitated by increased traffic, issues of £180,000 4 per cent. Debentures have been made during the past year.

The Board, having now exhausted the general powers of raising fresh share capital and Debentures granted them by the proprietors in 1898, are of opinion that it is advisable to increase the Preference Share Capital by the creation of £394,600, making the total Author Mised Preference Capital £1,250,000, which will enable the Board 'to provide funds as and when required for the completion of the Lines in hand and the further extensions contemplated.
A resolution to this effect, as printed on the back of this report, will be submitted to the meeting.

Auditors.
The proprietors will be asked to elect Auditors for the ensuing year. Messrs. Frank Davies, Meredith and Company, being eligible, offer themselves for re-election.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Lieutenant-Colonel H. F. M. Wilson, Rifle Brigade, commanding the 2nd Battalion in the Sudan, has been given the rank of brevet colonel. Lieutenant-Colonel G. F. Leslie, of the 4th Battalion, will receive a similar step next month.
The Assistant Adjutant General of the Egyptian Army, Captain E. S. Herbert, Black Watch, has been granted the local rank of major whilst employed in that capacity.
Lieutenant Arthur Berger, Army Service Corps, who lately returned home from Egypt on leave, remains here and has been posted to Woolwich for duty.

Lieutenant C. F. N. Bartlett, 1st Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, at Dublin, as already intimated, has been placed under orders to join the 2nd Battalion at Alexandria and will embark for that garrison about the 14th February next.

Second-Lieutenants F. G. Brown, G. W. Willock, and A. C. K. Magill, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, at Cairo, have been promoted lieutenants. All three officers served with the 2nd Battalion during its campaign in the Transvaal, Orange River Colony, and Cape Colony (medal with three clasps).

I understand that it was at the request of Lord Cromer that the M. M. P. in Egypt is being raised to the strength of a squadron. The Egyptian squadron is the very cream of the M. M. P. and every man of it has a clean
defaulter's sheet.
Herbert was promoted to the command of the battalion a couple years ago from second-in- command of the 3rd Battalion, then stationed at Cairo.

The new first-class battleship King Edward II. goes to the Mediterranean as flagship of Prince Louis of Battenberg. At her full power speed trials this week the battleship attained a speed of 18.7 knots per hour.

A Gibraltar correspondent claims that the results of the gun-layer's competitions in the Channel Fleet just brought to a close under the direction of. Vice-Admiral Lord Charles Beresford, have established a world's record. Six-inch guns were used and strict service conditions were observed. Each gun was allowed two minutes fire at a service target,
30ft. by 20ft., at a range commencing at 2,000 yards and finishing the run at 2,600 yards.
The total number of rounds fired was 227 and
The

It is believed that and West Indies station, holds the record with 19 rounds and 17 hits in two minutes, and the Caesar runs that close with 21 rounds and 18 hits. Sergeant Wall, Royal Marine Artillery, in the first minute fired 11 rounds and made scored seven hits in ten rounds Petty Officer as many hits. He caused to be fitted a loader, which resembles a gun until 36 rounds could be put through the in a casemate, and organised competitions loader in two minutes. He also arranged a tray, by means of which a projectile and cartridge can be lifted and put into the breech in one motion instead of two.

Construction et réparation des trottoirs.- L'augmentation de L.E. 250 provient de l'achat des regards en fer à placer sur les trottoirs à asphalter.

Construction des lanternes et urinoirs.- Le peu de largeur des trottoirs des rues de la ville, l'opposition systématique des pro- priétaires riverains à l'établissement d'uri- noirs ou chalets de nécessité ont fait que les crédits affectés à ces travaux n'ont pu être employés qu'en faible partie.

C'est pourquoi nous réduisons le crédit à L.E. 400 afin de nous permettre l'instal- lation d'un chalet de nécessité avec uri- noire, semblable à celui en cours d'exécu- tion à la Place Mohamed Aly, dans le parc de la rue d'Allemagne pour éviter que ce lieu de promenade ne devienne un dé- potoir.

Ce crédit comprend aussi la dépense de L.E. 400. qu'entraîne l'accord établi avec la Compagnie du Gaz pour avancer de 14 minutes l'horaire actuel d'allumage en compensation de l'espacement à 60 mètres de 125 lanternes commandées pour le fau bourg de Ramleh.

Relativement à cet accord, nous faisons remarquer qu'il a été fait en base du nom- bre de 3.751 lanternes fonctionnant en Juin 1904, et qu'il faudrait, après l'instal- lation des 125 lanternes à Ramleh, établir un double horaire, soit celui de la dernière convention pour 3.751 lanternes et l'ancien pour les lanternes en fonction en plus de ce nombre.

Il est inutile de remarquer que l'adop- tion de ces horaires constituerait une ano- malie dans l'allumage des lanternes d'au- tant plus que celles en cours d'installation se trouvent éparpillées dans tous 1-8 quar tiers de la ville.

Eclairage électrique.- Nous avons réduit le crédit à L.. 550 nécessaires au fonc- tionnement de 135 lampes qui resteront à Bamleh après le placement des 125 lan- ternes à gaz.

Relativement à l'éclairage de la ville, nous devons aussi rappeler qu'à plusieurs reprises l'attention de la Municipalité a été attirée sur l'insuffisance de l'éclairage de certaines artères principales de la Ville, notamment celles des rues Chérif Pachs, partie de la rue Rosette, Gare du Caire, Gare de Ramleb, Place Mohamed Aly, etc. A cet état de choses il a été, en partie, porté remède par l'établissement de lan- ternes supplémentaires à 3 becs et fonc- tionnant jusqu'à une heure du matin.

Par cette mesure nous ne croyons pas avoir répondu en entier au désir et aux exigences du public en tenant surtout compte que ces rues sont, durant toute l'année, très mouvementées et fréquentées pendant les premières heures de la nuit. C'est pourquoi l'adoption de l'éclairage électrique par des lampes à arc nous paraît être plus en rapport avec l'importance de ces roes..

ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT RESULTS of M. Legrain's discovery is the evidence it furnishes that up to the Greek age the Egyp- tian temples contained all the material needful for reconstructing the past history of the country. They were filled with inscribed statues and other monuments which formed a continuous series of contemporaneous docu- ments from the earliest period of the kingdom. Herodotus is thus shown to have said no more than the truth when he declared that Hecateus had seen at Thebes the statues of 345 high

div.head: CAIRO SEWAGE TRANSPORT CO., LIMITED.
div.p: NOTICE.
The Annual General Meeting of the Share-
d holders of the above-mentioned Company will
y be held on Saturday, the 24th day of Decem-
1-ber, 1904, at 4 p.m., at the Cairo offices of the es Company, Sharia Kasr-el-Nil.
The business to be transacted comprises the er following:
n 1.-Reading the report of the Directors in-ccluding the accounts for the twelve months
n ended 30th September, 1904, approving the
it
same and declaring a dividend.
2.-Reading the report of the Auditor.
3. Electing an Auditor for the year 1904-
st 1905 and fixing his remuneration.
of.
4.--Electing new Directors in accordance
d with Articles Nos. 37 and 38 of Articles of Association.
h

In accordance with the provisions of Art. 21 of the said Articles such shareholders as wish to be present at this meeting, either in person or by proxy, should deposit their shares with the Bankers of the Company in Cairo three days previous to the meeting, and the receipts alone, which they shall obtain in exchange, shall give the right to attend the meeting either personally or by proxy.
Shares will be received at the Bank of Egypt,
o Limited, from 9 o'clock to 11 up to the 21st December, 1904.
Cairo, 2nd December, 1904.
H. MEYER, Manager.

table.head: HORAIRE DES TRAINS A PARTIR DU 3 NOVEMBRE 1904

div.p: N.B. – Ne seront admis dans les deux trains No 3 et 24, que les voyageurs porteurs de billets de 1re et 2e classe seulement et les abonnés à ces deux classes. Le train No 16 ne s'arrêtera pas les Dimanches au garage Cozzika. – Le train No 22 s'arrêtera les Dimances à Massarah au lieu du train No 18.
N.B. Tous les mardis et les jeudis de chaque semaine, pendant la saison théâtrale à l'Opéra Khédivial le dernier train partira de Bab-el-Louk à 12h.45 au lieu de 12h.30.
Municipalité d'Alexandrie
AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication la construe
tion de guérites pour les cantonnie s
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau de la Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à.midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 20 Décembre prochain.

Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m. L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : "Soumission pour construction de guérites pour les cantonniers.

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis au Secrétaire Financier avant l'ouver ture des offres et au plus tard le 20 Décembre. 1904 & midi.
L'Administrateur. (Signé) W. P. CHATAWAY. Alexandrie, le 28 Novembre, 1904. 24979-3-8

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
The Egyptian Delta Light Railways,
LIMITED.

ANNUAL ORDINARY GENERAL MEETING of the Company will be held in Hall No. 43, Winchester House, Old Broad- Street, in the City of London, on TUESDAY, 20th DECEMBER, 1904, at 12 o'clock noon précisely, or the purpose of receiving the Directors' Report and Balance Sheet for the period ended 30th September, 1904, electing Directors in the place of the three retiring by rotation appointing Auditors for the ensuing year and fixing their remuneration, declaring a Dividend, and transacting the Ordinary General Business of the Company, and also for the purpose of considering and, if thought fit, passing the following Resolution then intended to be proposed that is to say:

THAT the capital of the Company be increased by the creation of 38,400 new Preference shares of the nominal amount of £10 each, and that such Preference shares be issued and allotted by the Board upon such terms and conditio as they may determine, but such onares shall be issued upon the terms (subject to the powers of the Board under Article 165 to set aside Sinking Funds and otherwise) that the surplus profits in each year after providing for a dividend on the amounts from time to time paid or credited as paid otherwise than in advance on all Preference shares at the rate of 5 per cent. for such year shall be applied first in making up the arrears of dividend on the Preference Snares of the Company previously issued in respect of the périod previous to the date of issue of the new Preference Shares hereby authorised, and when those arrears have been paid then in paying up the arrears (if any) which may subse- quently accrue on all Preference Shares in the order in which such arrears may be accrued and thereafter the sum of 10s. d. per cent. per annum on the said $34,600 of new Capital as part of the sinking rund heretofore authorised in respect of the previous Capital so as to insure the repayment of the whole of the Share Capital authorised up to the date hereof in its due order of priority under the Articles. Save as aforesaid the said new Preference Shares of the Company. Dated this 30th day of November, 1904. By order of the Board,
11, GRESHAM HOUSE,
F. J. HORNE,
OLD BROAD STREET, LONDON, E.C.
Secretary.
N.B.-Shareholders who hold Share Warrants to

Bearer and whose names are not on the share Registers of the Company are reminded that if they wish to attend this General Meeting of the Company, they must first deposit their Bearer Warrants together with a statement in writing of their names and addresses at the Registered Offices of the Company in London two clear days before the date of the General Meeting, viz. :- not later than the 17th December, 1904, or wish the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo or Alexandria, ten clear days before the date of the General Meeting, vis. : not later than the 9th December, 1904. The Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held Each Depositor will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange for Share Warrants deposit. ed which must be produced by the Holders attending the Meeting.
Dividend Warrants will be issued on the 28rd December, 1904. 24995-8-2
Egyptian Delta Light Railways.
TENDERS FOR COAL.
Tenders are invited for the supply of 1,200 tons if the best Cardiff Coal, as required during the nonth of December, 1904.
The prices should be quoted in EGYPTIAN CURRENCY for delivery "free in trucks, Gabbary."

Tenders to specify accurately and clearly the class and description of coal offered, the percentage of lust and whether delivery is from chip or Quays.. The certificate of the Colliery will have to be reduced if called for.
The Company does not bind itself to accept the lowest or any tender.

Tenders should be sent in before noon on the 5th December, 1904; addressed to the Agent and General Manager, Egyptian Delta Light Railway, 20. Box No. 669, Cairo, under sealed cover, superaribed "Tender for Coal," 24969-8-8
